Following concerns for public safety that were heightened by the collapse of the Civic Tower of Pavia in 1989, the tower was closed to the public on 7 January 1990 to undergo stabilization efforts. These efforts were critical in preserving the tower, which was constructed with a blend of Romanesque and Gothic elements by Tommaso di Andrea Pisano. Notably, construction phases were overseen by individuals like Benenato, son of Gerardo Bottici, who took charge on 27 December 1233, and later by Guido Speziale, son of Giovanni Pisano, who was elected on 23 February 1260. The tower's unique tilt, originally unintended and resulting from foundation issues, has been scrutinized for its vulnerability to seismic activity. A 2018 investigation revealed that the tower’s survival over centuries, even in the face of earthquakes, is due to the interplay between its height and construction materials with the softness of the foundation soil, preventing it from resonating with earthquake ground motions. This phenomenon was recognized internationally when the Italian government sought global assistance on 27 February 1964 to prevent its collapse. Although the Tower of Pisa was once deemed the world's most lopsided building, it was later surpassed by the Capital Gate building in Abu Dhabi, UAE, which was certified by Guinness World Records in June 2010 for having a deliberate 18-degree slope, significantly more pronounced than that of the Tower of Pisa.

Discovered by major league umpire Tim Hurst while working YMCA games, Connolly began his umpiring career in the New England League from 1894 to 1897. In 1931, he was appointed the American League's first supervisor of umpires by new AL president Will Harridge, in response to concerns about the quality of umpiring. Connolly made history by umpiring in the American League for 31 years, a record later broken by Larry Barnett in 1999. He worked in an AL-record eight World Series and was the sole arbiter of the first AL game ever played on April 24, 1901. Recognized for his contributions to baseball, Connolly was named in the Honor Rolls of Baseball in 1946 and was elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1953, becoming one of the first two umpires, alongside Bill Klem, to receive this honor. Connolly passed away in 1961 at the age of 90 in Natick, Massachusetts, leaving behind a legacy in the world of sports officiating.

rewrite sen: John Keats's work was so influential that it affected many famous poets and writers after him, including the moment when, inspired by Charles Cowden Clarke in October 1816, he penned "On First Looking into Chapman's Homer." This sonnet was a reflection of his exhilaration upon encountering George Chapman's bold and vigorous 1616 translation of Homer, a perspective introduced to him by Clarke, his mentor since his boarding school days in Enfield Town. Clarke's influence extended beyond just introducing Keats to Chapman’s translation; together, they spent a night immersed in the text, with Keats expressing his excitement loudly as passages struck his imagination. Despite the prevailing popularity of the refined translations by John Dryden and Alexander Pope among Keats’s contemporaries, which presented Homer with an urbane finesse, Keats and Clarke shared a preference for the more robust paraphrasing of Chapman. Additionally, Keats's sonnet encapsulates the wonder of discovery, likening his experience to that of astronomers like Herschel, whom Keats would have learned about from Johnny Bonnycastle’s "An Introduction to Astronomy," a book he won while at Enfield Academy. Furthermore, Keats creatively merged elements from William Robertson's "History of America," notably conflating the experiences of Balboa and Cortés, demonstrating the poet's inventive engagement with historical and literary texts.

She is recognized as one of the four couples traditionally believed to be interred in the Cave of the Patriarchs, alongside Isaac, Adam and Eve, Abraham and Sarah, and Jacob and Leah. The events surrounding Rebecca's death hint that she lived to approximately 120 or 134 years old, as discerned from various Midrashic interpretations of her life, notably impacted by Jacob's age of 97 after spending 20 years with Laban at the time of her passing. Additionally, the burial of Deborah, Rebecca's nurse, at Alon Bachuth, or "Tree of Weepings," signified a period of mourning that was further underscored by the Midrashic interpretation of a "double sorrow" at Rebecca's death. Her life, marked by the moment she dismounted from her camel upon seeing Isaac in the fields of Beer-lahai-roi, and the revival of three miracles in Sarah's tent upon her arrival, remains a significant narrative within Jewish tradition, even influencing customs in traditional Jewish wedding ceremonies today.

rewrite sen: Sons and Lovers, a seminal 1913 novel by the English writer D.H. Lawrence, is heralded as one of his most significant works. This semi-autobiographical masterpiece not only probes deep into personal family conflicts, as Lawrence channels his experiences through the characters of William and Paul Morel, but also artfully navigates Paul Morel's complex relationships with his lovers, under the shadow of his devotion to his mother. The work's importance is underlined by its ranking as ninth on the Modern Library's list of the 100 best novels in English of the 20th century in 1999 and its inclusion in The Western Canon by critic Harold Bloom in 1994, as one of the books that have significantly influenced Western culture. Its journey to publication was marked by a critical title change from the initially planned Paul Morel to the more thematic Sons and Lovers, a decision that reinvigorated Lawrence's defense of his novel as a cohesive artistic statement. Adaptations of this novel, including the Academy Award-winning 1960 film, a 1981 BBC TV serial, and a 2003 ITV1 adaptation, attest to its enduring appeal and impact on literature and culture.
